Work around build errors on musl libc (#4535)

* Work around build errors on musl libc

Currently musl does not support GLOB_TILDE but it is on their roadmap
[1]. This patch is no fix and changes functionality for musl. A slightly
changed functionality seems better than being unable to build.

For glibc and future versions of musl this change is a noop.

[1] https://wiki.musl-libc.org/roadmap.html

Merge pull request #4530 from supercollider/3.10

3.10 -> develop
class library: Add ServerOptions:bindAddress

supernova: Add dummy -B option

This commit adds a dummy -B option to supernova that exists only so that command-line option strings can be compatible between scsynth and supernova.
scsynth: Provide better command-line documentation for -B

scsynth: Set default socket address to 127.0.0.1

This commit changes the default socket address, user-settable from the command line via the -B option, to 127.0.0.1 rather than 0.0.0.0. For most users running laptops connected to wifi, 0.0.0.0 is a dangerous default, since it allows anyone on the local network to send OSC messages to scsynth.

See issue #4496 for more explanation.

Merge pull request #4454 from mtmccrea/topic/simplenumber-series

Topic/simplenumber series

PyrMathPrim: remove spaces in empty line.

Looks like this wasn't caught by clang-format, but is caught in CI?
PyrMathPrim format with clang-format
[Test] add SimpleNumber:series test that for step == 0 and first == last, return [ first ]

PyrMathPrim: prSimpleNumberSeries catch float step of 0.0

When caught, the size is set to 1 for consistency with the behavior of the Int type.
PyrMathPrim: prSimpleNumberSeries slight reformatting of errors for readability.
sc_plugin_interface::buffer_write: properly throw exception when buffer can't be written (instead of return -1)

synth: Prevent data from being freed twice in AsyncPlugInCmd (#4456)

* synth: Prevent completion message data from being freed twice in AsyncPlugInCmd. Resolves issue #4338

Without this, World_Free is called on the same memory twice, as SequencedCmd also frees this pointer. This then causes the FIFO queue on the thread to get into trouble and render the server unresponsive.

* Correct formatting
handle_b_write: ensure correct order of completion message -> done message in
sc_osc_handler.cpp: make sure that all /done messages are sent as "io_callbacks" to ensure message ordering
remove suggestion to use @refspec in git URL [skip ci]

Update nova external libraries
[docs] add clarification to SimpleNumber:series
Add unit test for SimpleNumber:series

Fix array size calculation for arithmetic series with a step that doens't evenly divide into range.

Previously, when a float type was specified and the step size didn't divide evenly into the range, the last value in the resultant array overshot the specied 'last' value. This wouldn't happen with int inputs.

Update nova external libraries

This change pulls in a FSF address fix in nova-simd and nova-tt headers.

Create a new LinkClock object which starts with the same tempo, beats

Merge pull request #4314 from supercollider/master

master -> develop

Plotter:-domainCoordinates: add more explicit check for domainSpec range of 0.0.

Handle that and data size of 1 by plotting the value(s) in the center
of the plot.
Plotter:-updatePlotSpecs: when superposing plots, new specs should combine range of all sub-plots, not default to that of the first plot.
Plotter:-dataCoordinates: allow domain set to nil, error check for unsupported data dimensions.
Plotter:-superpose: restore default arg to setValue call and restore previous domain state when toggle superpose to false.
Test: add unit test for Plotter:-plotColors
Docs-Plotter: add two domain/domainSpecs setting examples
Plotter:-plotColor rename to -plotColors for consistency with other plural setters.
Docs: document Plotter:-setValue method.
Plotter:-superpose: follow the instance variable findSpecs when toggling superpose.
Plotter: fix behavior of bars plot mode when domain is set and editMode = true.
Docs-Plotter: Document behavior of domain and domainSpec, as well as the new plotColor method.
Plotter: clean up comments and deleted code related to domain behavior bug fixes.
Plotter:-setValue: bug fix - set domain to nil to prevent error if new value size is mismatched from old value size.

Plotter:-setValue: bug fix - calc domain specs before value specs to ensure domain updates correctly when values are updated.

Before, the domainSpecs would display the previous domain until a

class library: fix setbus_control Event type

The Event type \setbus_control is intended to be used for crossfading
between values on a control bus. There are cases in which a previously
playing synth still writes on the bus after the fadeTime (this can
happen due to a slightly later release of the other crossfade
envelope). Then the target value that the control bus should have after
transition is lost.

Adding one control period to the envelope as a hold value is a way to
avoid this glitch.

This fixes  #4295.

qtcollider: swallow events (please read full msg)

In QtCollider::notify(), explicitly accept all handled events so they
don't propagate outside the application.  This is a hack; for a
not-fully-understood reason Qt past 5.7 sends these events to the native
window if they aren't accepted here. This caused issue #4058. Accepting
them here seems to solve the problem, but might cause other issues since
it is a heavy-handed way of doing this.

Based on looking at Qt's source code I have a strong guess this happens
because we set AA_MacPluginApplication on the QtCollider application.
See https://code.qt.io/cgit/qt/qtbase.git/tree/src/plugins/platforms/cocoa/qnsview.mm?h=5.11#n1472

AFAICT we shouldn't be setting that flag because it is meant for Qt
_plugins_ only, and QtCollider is an application, not a plugin using the
Qt QPluginLoader system. But, removing that setting causes QtCollider to
take focus after starting up, an undesirable side effect. There might be
a way to fix that, I don't know.

At any rate AA_MacPluginApplication is deprecated in favor of
AA_PluginApplication, so I have swapped it out with that and left a
TODO.

Simple tests show that this works; at least, it lets events propagate up
the widget hierarchy within a window while still blocking e.g. Cmd-B
from booting the server.

Fixes #4058 (?)

Merge pull request #4055 from brianlheim/topic/cmake_gen

Add tools/cmake_gen

Plotter:-domainCoordinates: add more explicit check for domainSpec range of 0.0.

Handle that and data size of 1 by plotting the value(s) in the center
of the plot.
Plotter:-updatePlotSpecs: when superposing plots, new specs should combine range of all sub-plots, not default to that of the first plot.
Plotter:-dataCoordinates: allow domain set to nil, error check for unsupported data dimensions.
Plotter:-superpose: restore default arg to setValue call and restore previous domain state when toggle superpose to false.

Fix FunctionDef:argumentString

```argumentString``` did not handle varArgs correctly, adding a default of ```[ ]```. varArgs cannot have defaults.

One side effect of this is that archives containing open Functions would be uninterpretable. The correct behaviour is that the open function is archived with args but does nothing. (This is what happens without varArgs.)

Merge pull request #3978 from snappizz/topic/cherrypick-3950

Cherrypick #3950 onto 3.10

[scide] Force using Qt widgets in Fusion style, to avoid platform issues.

This allows deprecation of the Mac OSX-specific tweaks, because the colors don't
have to render on top of both native controls and Qt controls.
[scide] tweaks selection highlight color for better contrast

[scide] clamps selection background color to usable values on OS X.

UI colors on OS X have to sometimes work well on top of hard-coded white
background colors as Qt uses a mix of Cocoa native and Qt-rendered controls
on this platform.
[scide] fix build
[scide] cleanup of some now unneeded modifications to main

[scide] adjustments to ui palette value separation heuristic

The old heuristic reacted to a value difference of only 16, but this allowed
for some cases where the user could provide colors with input values that would
not be separated by 32 units of value, which from testing makes the UI less
usable. The new code always distances the colors by 32 units of value.

[scide] additional tweaks to ide colors for usability and beauty

Sets the disabled text foreground and shadow colors to better match the theme.
Sets the highlighted text foreground and background to fit rest of theme
  active and inactive colors.
If the user mistakenly sets text foreground and background colors too close
  together for readable contrast we nudge them apart for usability.

[scide] further refinements to adapting ui colors to window theme

Dropped the two contrast background colors to one, and tweaked the logic
about active and inactive tab color selection for a more uniform look.

[scide] Adds some refinement based on testing on MacOS X.

Testing all default provided color themes on MacOS exposed a few issues:

Light text on dark backgrounds breaks buttons on OS X which are always rendered
with the system background color of white, making the text unreadable. We
clamp colors to a certain lightness on OS X to prevent this.

Generally the active tab needs to be highlighted with a different color.

There are still a few questions and refinements here, going to test back on
my Linux machine later this evening. Thinking of swapping the active tab
and inactive tab colors.

scide: ui colors now reflect editor colors in settings.

Regarding #3792, this forces the UI colors to track the changes to the colors
in the settings menu. We set the colors on startup as well as update the colors
each time the settings are applied.

Merge pull request #3966 from brianlheim/topic/templatesyay

improve PR & issue templates

help-browser: use webchannel to submit eval requests

shift-enter needs to be intercepted at the JS level and call a slot on a C++ object
in order to evaluate a line. This shortcut isn't propagated normally.
This commit adds QWebChannel and QWebSockets to the dependencies
and uses them to allow JS to request the help browser C++ code to evaluate a line.

Also some changes to JS code and SCDoc renderer code

Note that the WebChannel should only be loaded on pages with code to
execute.

The WebChannel is constructed in the IDE's main() and then a new wrapper
for IDE objects is published to it. On the JS side, evaluateLine() is
called whenever shift-enter on a code snippet is detected.

IDE: greater control over adding editor tabs

Fixes #3941

Previously adding tabs from a session resulted in backwards ordering
because of changes made in #3053 -- restored tabs were now inserted next
to the current index instead of at the end. This commit changes `addTab`
to `insertTab` and allows tabs to be inserted at any index, including
the previous default behavior (when the requested index is negative)

Introduces functions:

convert sclang strings and collections of strings to C++ std:strings and vector of std::string.
boost::variant<int,std::string> slotStdStrVal(PyrSlot *slot)
boost::variant<int,std::string> slotStrStdStrVal(PyrSlot *slot)
boost::variant<int, std::vector<std::string>> PyrCollToVectorStdString(PyrObject *coll)

boost::optional<std::tuple<pid_t, FILE *>> sc_popen(std::string &&command, const std::string &type)
boost::optional<std::tuple<pid_t, FILE *>> sc_popen_argv(const std::vector<std::string> &strings, const std::string &type)

linux:
boost::optional<std::tuple<pid_t, FILE *>> sc_popen_c_argv(const char *filename, char *const argv[], const char *type)

On linux sc_popen calls sc_popen_argv creating a shell process to run the command, and  sc_popen_argv calls sc_popen_c_argv.

windows:
std::tuple<FILE *, pid_t> sc_popen_c(const char *utf8_cmd, const char *mode)

On windows sc_popen_argv calls sc_popen with a command line created by joining the strings with spaces as delimiters and sc_popen calls sc_popen_c.

class library: Improve SerialPort.devices

This commit makes the following changes to SerialPort.devices:

- Add more rules for matching device patterns, imported from the Arduino
  IDE.
- Document SerialPort.devicePattern as a legacy feature. It makes two
  wrong assumptions:
  - Devices can be effectively matched using simple
    file globbing (Linux/macOS require regexps, and Windows requires
    running a command and parsing its output).
  - SerialPort.devices actually needs this kind of customization. It's
    not hard at all to get finer control by post-processing its output
    or just rewriting this simple method.
- Emit a deprecation warning if a number is passed for the "port"
  argument to SerialPort. Brittle and unnecessary convenience.

class library: Implement SerialPort.devices for Windows

This commit adds a working implementation of SerialPort.devices for
Windows by inspecting the HKLM\HARDWARE\DEVICEMAP\SERIALCOMM registry
key.

lang: Fix remaing users of QObjectProxy

QObjectProxy was used in a few places as a sort of psuedo-generic type, probably just to avoid having to create a type converter for a new type. We now have the right type conversions for these, and in general this is a bad pattern: we should stick to (roughly) 1:1 relationships between sclang types and C++ types, else it becomes very hard to map between them correctly.

soundfileview: process data in float, correct line width (#3662)

This improves the soundfileview widget.
The main underlying change is that the data is always read and stored in float (previously short int), which allows representing values outside of the +-1.0 range.
The line width got also corrected to be always 1px, so the waveform doesn't disappear anymore on large zoom in.

Simple benchmark did not show significant performance difference from the previous implementation.

* soundfileview: scale bounding lines according to yZoom

* soundfileview: set cosmetic QPen for drawing the waveform (always 1px)

* soundfileview: process all data in float

* soundfileview: fade out RMS plot on lower frame-per-pixel values, also fix float limits

* soundfileview: change calculating rmsColor when using _waveColors

* soundfileview: add _drawsRMS parameter

* soundfilveview help: add descriptions of peakColor, rmsColor, waveColors

* soundfileview: add yOffset parameter

* soundfileview help: note on (no-op) elasticMode

* soundfileview: add spacing parameter

* soundfileview: add antialiasing, drawsCenterLine, and drawsBoundingLines parameters

* soundfileview help: add information about default values

* soundfileview: remove antialiasing option

build: Ensure CMake only finds Qt 5.7+

The current build system sometimes digs up components from old Qt
versions without verifying that they are a compatible version (5.7+).
This comment adds a minimum Qt version requirement to the call to
`find_package` to ensure this never happens. This prevents some
inconsistent states where Qt components are mixed and matched.

sclang: fix hang on floating point arguments to Integer:forBy

Previously Integer:forBy would truncate floating point arguments, to integers,
which could potentially result in an infinite loop by the Integer:forBy
optimized special operation. This modification checks for any of the arguments
to be floating point, and if detecting that casts all of the arguments to
floating point. It also adds appropriate testing coverage.

class library: function play fade envelope when necessary

Currently, the GraphBuilder that wraps the UGens in function.play
always makes a fade envelope, unless the output is a scalar.

Instead, this should be done only when absolutely necessary. When the
Ugen graph has already an envelope that is able to release the synth,
we avoid making another envelope.

This fixes #3768.

#testing: this may have an impact on some past workarounds tha uses
{ }.play, or internally makes use of the GraphBuilder. This is an API
change.

sclang: now correctly copies objects in Array::lace

Previous modifications to the Array::lace function dropped the copy
for objects that aren't lists or arrays. To test:
[ { 1.0.rand }, [ 10, 20 ], [ 100, 200, 300 ] ].lace(7) returns
[ a Function, 10, 100, a Function, 20, 200, a Function ].

add bars mode

sclang: narrow scope of setting nil in Array::lace to empty arrays

Regarding issue #3716, based on feedback on the PR, we will only
set nil in the target array if trying to copy a zero-length array.
Note that this leaves the code behaving as the unmodified version
of the code, which is that objects in the callee array that are
neither lists or arrays will not be copied.

class library: NodeProxy crossfade shape

Setting the gate of an envelope to a negative value makes a forced
release. What remained unnoticed here was that the forced release shape
is always linear, regardless of the envelope’s shape. This commit
replaces the forced release by a normal release. The fadeTime is set,
so forcing wasn’t necessary.

This fixes #3775.

testing:
- test how node object replacement and freeing sounds.
- this may change the behaviour of SynthDefs that are separately made
and which do not define a `fadeTime` parameter to specify the release
time. A subsequent commit will try to minimize such impact.

sclang: substitutes nil for empty subarrays in Array::lace

Based on feedback in issue #3716, out-of-bound access to arrys results
in nil, so when iterating through empty subarrays in Array::lace we
return nil instead of [].

sclang: fixes crash on call to Array::lace with empty subarrays

Regarding issue #3716, this fixes two bugs:

a) Calls to lace with no length argument would fail if any elements in the
array weren't subarrays. Now lace will assume the max length of each
subelement is one.

b) Calls to lace with empty subarrays would crash due to a divide-by-zero
error in running modulo to calculate the lace index on a subarray of length
zero. Now the code simply copies the empty subarray into place in the ouput
array.

class library: remove pushNow argument.

This argument (`pushNow`) can be a very confusing option when set to
false. It creates a document which will be linked properly to the
environment only after losing focus and then coming back. For documents
that are not in focus, on the other hand, it is much better not to
push. This avoids user errors.

This is an API change.

Merge pull request #3613 from aspiers/rm-support-dir-deprecation

Remove misleading deprecation of old support directory

Remove misleading deprecation of old support directory

On UNIX-like systems, if SuperCollider is compiled from source into
the user's home directory via:

    cmake -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$HOME
    make install

then Platform.systemAppSupportDir and Platform.resourceDir will be set
to

    $HOME/share/SuperCollider

This is due to CMakeLists.txt containing the definition of SC_DATA_DIR:

    elseif(UNIX)
            add_definitions(-DSC_DATA_DIR="${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/share/SuperCollider")
    endif()

which is then consumed by common/SC_Filesystem_unix.cpp.

Unfortunately, this resulting path is identical to the old location
for the *user* support directory, so it triggers a misleading warning.
However this deprecation was introduced by 2b77ef67 in August 2011,
so it should be safe to remove it by now.

Fixes #3367.

UnitTest: add option to hide details of passed assertions

When assertions succeed, we don't usually need to see the details;
they just clutter up the output.  So extend #-assert's API with an
extra details parameter, to optionally allow separation of the main
test description message from the details, and introduce a new
class variable passVerbosity, which if set to UnitTest.brief,
suppresses output of the details whenever an assertion passes.

The responsibility of formatting the report of an individual test
result should either fall entirely with UnitTestResult, or not all,
but not partially.  The former seems like a more sensible choice, so
pass the new details parameter to UnitTestResult in order that it may
handle the formatting of those details along with the other info.

This should be 100% backwards-compatible for existing callers.

Partially addresses #3365.

UnitTest: skip a trailing " - " if there is no message to follow it

Not all tests provide messages, in which case a trailing " - " looks
ugly, so don't output it.

UnitTest: put a space after PASS: and FAIL:

It's a fraction more legible this way.

class library: only schedule messages if necessary

The message schedBundleArrayOnClock is sent to a number in order to
send off an OSC bundle a after certain time. If that time equals zero,
there is no need to add the task to the clock’s queue. This commit adds
a case where the bundle is send right now without scheduling it on the
clock in that case.

Merge pull request #3478 from snappizz/topic/move-malloc-aligned

Move malloc_aligned.hpp out of supernova and into common

Move malloc_aligned.hpp out of supernova and into common

`server/supernova/utilities/malloc_aligned.hpp` is part of supernova,
but both sclang and scsynth include it. This commit moves the file to
`common/` to better reflect its dependencies.

Both `include/common/` or `common/` are possible locations for this
file, but to my understanding `include/common/` is for APIs exposed to
third parties, which we probably don't want here.

This fixes #3362.

supernova: reserve enough size for synthdefs

In sc_synthdef::prepare(void), the memory requirement for a sc_synth
structure was underreported because it did not change with #3063.

issue and adds clarifying comments to the calculations.

class library: implement correct stop behaviour for Task

Routines can’t stop in between yields. Nevertheless, `Routine`
implements a trick in `stop`: it checks if it is in the current thread
and if it is, it will yield nil, breaking calculation right where it is.

Because a `Task` has a routine and is not a routine, it needs to do
this check as well, but this time for its stream.

scdoc: Fix rippling links on hover

This commit fixes links in SCDoc, particularly those in the top drop-
down menus, changing size when the cursor hovers over them. This is due
to a "padding-bottom: 1px" line in the CSS that attempts to compensate
for "text-decoration: underline" not appearing when the font size is
less than 11pt, but I don't see any such problem.

Supernova: use LIB_SUFFIX for plugin loading

Commit 547a18c introduced the CMake variable LIB_SUFFIX to determine the
system library folder, and made supernova load plugins in both /usr/lib
and /usr/lib64.
On some systems (eg archlinux64) lib64 is symlinked to lib, supernova then
tries to load the plugins twice and crashes.
We want supernova to load only the folder in which the plugins have been
installed.

class library: plot relative to target synth

Sometimes, one needs to plot values from a synth that depends on node
order. E.g. a synth that reads from a bus. This patch allows us to
determine the point at which the plotting synth is inserted in the node
order. It is inserted _after_ the target node. By default, this is the
default group of the default server. This follows the `asTarget`
interface, as documented in scdoc.

sclang: add newline when posting exception message

If an exception is caught while running a primitive, the exception's
message should be followed by a newline so that it doesn't run on into the
next "ERROR" message.

Fix prFileOpen

Without using slotRawObject(b)->size, there's no null char at the
end of the string. This rolls back what seemed like a previous
optimization which actually produced garbage strings because of
the lack of null from slotRawString(b)->s.

Support UTF-8 in some file primitives

Use a combination of SC_Filesystem methods and bfs methods to
convert all OS path strings to UTF-8 when passing to sclang, and to
native encoding when passing to filesystem operations.

Primitives which are not yet working are: prFileOpen, getcwd

Many internal file primitives (like close, flush, pos, length, putInt32)
are left untouched, because they only rely on data passed to a file
pointer.

SoundFile primitives have not been converted yet.

implementation is platform-independent.

instead of const std::string

class library: avoid clock inconsistency

an inconsistency can happen when the clock’s tempos was set to <= 0 via
`etempo_()` (prTempoClock_SetTempoAtTime), and then later one tries to
set it again to a new value via `tempo_()`
(prTempoClock_SetTempoAtBeat). Then beats become `nan`. This protects
`tempo_()` from being called in such a situation.

class library: clock dependants should be notified

notification of dependants also happens when tempo is set via
`etempo_()`.

class library: fix possible sync problem in NodeProxy clear (#2845)

class library: fix possible sync problem in NodeProxy clear

`MixedBundle` allows to schedule a function when sending happens. This
is what was used to schedule into the future the clearing of the old
group. It is much better to just delegate this to the server. Because
group  objects are registered by NodeProxy with the NodeWatcher, it is
also released correctly. ( `NodeWatcher.newFrom(s).nodes`).

We need to add a very small offset between the bundle timestamps, so their order is guaranteed on the server.

Make primitive exception handling per-PyrThread

- We cannot store exception info directly in the PyrThread, as PyrThreads are never constructed in the normal C++ sense (made in the GC pool), so we store it instead in a map in the VMGlobals instance, using the thread as a key.
- this makes it both per-thread, and supports any future implementations using multiple VMs.

Merge pull request #2863 from telephon/topic-reduce-needs-adverb

class library: adverb argument for reduce

Fix SC try / catch behaviour for primitive exception errors

- the previous version posted exception errors in doPrimitive, rather than setting them in the Error via prPrimitiveErrorString as for other primitive errors. This prevented sclang try / catch from truly catching the error.
- This could be annoying in cases like network music situations, where a stream of errors resulting from another host going down could not be handled as desired even though the problem had nothing to do with SC, or even the local machine.
- this version fixes that, and makes the error message clearer and more informative

Signed-off-by: Scott Wilson <i@scottwilson.ca>

class library: adverb argument for reduce

The method `reduce` takes a binary operator selector (or an appropriate
function) and applies it to the collection’s items incrementally.

This patch allows us to pass an adverb to the operator, as commonly
expected for binary operations. If the operator is a function, the
adverb is the third argument.

These two expressions return the same value:
```
[1, 2] *.t [10, 20, 30]
[[1, 2], [10, 20, 30]].reduce('*', 't')
```

This feature is justified because it exposes the interface of binary
operators and calculations by reduce are very compact.

class library: NodeProxy - tolerant handling of nested output

In many situations, one would expect `proxy.ar` to return a single
channel, but it returns an array (there are good reasons for this,
discussed in NodeProxy help under routing).

But in order to avoid being overly strict, we treat a singleton channel
as a channel for a proxy _input_ (that is the result of the UGen
function).

It will still warn if there are more UGens in the nested arrays.

qt: Remove unused symbol

qt: Switch to QWebEngineView / QWebEnginePage.

The capabilities of QWebEngine* are significantly different than those of the previous QWebPage/QWebView, so the QWebView class was substantially refactored to reflect the new API's. Properties and signals exposed in sclang now follow their Qt counterparts more closely, to make maintainence and upgrades more straightforward in the future. Some calls, such as toHTML and toPlainText, have become asynchronous - these are implemented on the sclang side by passing a callback function as the first argument, which is converted to a QcCallback object and used to signal the language with the results. Though this is only used in webview's currently, it should be easily portable to other async callback cases in sclang if needed.

Merge pull request #2793 from snappizz/topic/sf-info-initialization

scsynth: /b_read[Channel]: fix failure in sf_open caused by uninitialized memory

scsynth: initialize memory for SF_INFO structs

This fixes an uninitialized memory issue in /b_read and /b_readChannel, which was causing nondeterministic failures in Buffer.cueSoundFile. libsndfile's sf_open takes as input a pointer to an SF_INFO struct, to which it writes its soundfile metadata. However, the SF_INFO struct's "format" parameter of the struct must be set to zero, otherwise (as best as I can tell from the sf_open docs) the audio is read in a RAW format. Failure to initialize the SF_INFO memory is therefore a bad idea, and zeroing out the memory ensures that the RAW format is not accidentally invoked.

scsynth: CoreAudio: workaround for rate check

The scsynth CoreAudio driver checks to make sure that the sample rates of the input and output devices are the same, and if they are not, an error message is produced and scsynth refuses to boot. This commit skips the check if the number of input bus channels is 0. This allows the command-line option "-i 0" to serve as a simple workaround if the user would prefer to simply ignore the input device.

populate sclang-class-list

Prevent Emacs fontification failure w/ lots of classes - Fixes #248

What I've done to fix this:

- add a sclang-class-list variable in sclang-language.el, which is a
  list of all the classes known to sclang. this is populated when
  sclang starts.
- update sclang-font-lock-class-keyword-matcher in
  sclang-mode.el. since the sclang-class-name-regexp now will match
  all words that start with a capital letter (see next bullet point
  for that change), this function had to be updated to check to make
  sure that the word starting with a capital letter is in the list of
  classes. if it is, then we know it's a class and it gets
  highlighted. if it's not, then it's just something the user typed
  with a capital letter, so we don't highlight it.
- update sclang-update-font-lock in sclang-mode.el. instead of
  generating a huge regexp from a list of all the classes in
  SuperCollider, just run the normal fontification from that
  function. this avoids making the regexp too big and thus prevents
  fontification from failing.

class library: node proxy adjust OSC values in event

This patch ensures the expansion of static values to the proxie’s
number of channels, unless the reshaping is elastic.

It also protects the curve from being zero.

class library: setBus event permits changing signal

Instead of just sampling the old signal on the bus, the setBus event
now crossfades continuously. Because this is an API change, and the old
behaviour is reasonable in some cases, too, we provide an easy switch
(the boolean ~hold).

This fixes #2456
class library: killed server process notifies sclang
class library: recorder can record bus directly

class library: allow several recorders running

This commit simply makes the change notifications switchable.

class library: server recovers more gracefully

The server model checks before boot if it can reach its address. If
this works, it quits the server app first, so that it doesn’t run into
duplicate clientIDs. This allows us to recover better when sclang has
crashed and couldn’t release its server notification id and its shared
memory.

Topic/rate fallthrough (#1835)

* class library: assume scalar rate as minimum

When determining the rate of a collection of objects, the maximal rate
is returned. Now if the rate happens to be nil, we just assume scalar.
This allows the error to be thrown a bit later, in the UGen that takes
the object as an input. This fixes #1771

* class library: use explicit parentheses

… as not to give rise to confusions and assume the function as the
receiver of minItem.

* class library: throw error when Out has input nil

Normally, this kind of error is caught in `checkValidInputs`. But as
the args are appended, and nil just appends itself as nothing, we never
see this as an input - it simply is missing. This commit explicitly
checks the input size.

Fix TCP connect for IPs > 127.x.x.x

32-bit IPs from sclang are read as signed integers. They thus need to be
interpreted/cast to unsigned for IPs > 127.x.x.x to be valid. This is
already done for UDP ports, but has been forgotten to be taken care of
for TCP ports.

sclang: Refactor out more QObjectProxy conversions

Now done by generic QObject TypeCodec
sclang: Change some QObjectProxy interfaces to use generic QObject TypeCodec.
sclang: remove unneccesary fwd declaration.

sclang: Generic TypeCodec for lists

This provides a TypeCodec for e.g. functions that return QList/QVector types.

sclang: Generic QObject-descendant TypeCodec

This TypeCodec can be used to convert read and write any QObject-derived class. This allows hooking directly into meta-calls that take QObject-derived types as arguments.

In the read case, it checks to see if the slot contains a QObjectProxy. If so, it attempts to qobject_cast it to the requested type, else it provides a null pointer. Note that read == safeRead: this will always provide a null pointer in cases where the type conversion doesn't work.

In the write case, we simply do the reverse - cast to the expected type, and then convert as a QObject, which will connect with it's QObjectProxy (if it exists).

Fix QLocalSocket problem under Windows. Still Work in Progress.

For now, it fixes the Windows crash, so this should enable us to move
the Windows development to master again, which we should try to do ASAP.

Since QLocalSocket under Windows is unreliable (it might cut messages),
it is not advised to use QDataStream.

I have changed it to a messaging system based on strings and REs. At the
beginning of each message we put the length of the message, so that the
receiving side knows how much to retrieve.

The change for now is only for the messages coming from SCProcess to
sc_ipc_client direction. *I don't know if something similar needs to be
done in the other direction, or where...*

Fix DemandEnvGen overshooting at high curve

Fixes #1355 

* Correct an overshoot reported in bug 1355. This overshoot happens because
the curve is "grown" an integer number of times (==phase) but the growth
factor is set to exp( curve / count ) (where count is initialized as phase)
so at very high curve, that small 0.3 of an extra phase being different than the
1 of the extra count gets amplified. Fix the problem by setting the growth rate
to match the actual number of applications, which is exp( curve / ceil( count ) ).
This will mean there's a slight inconsistency in very high curve oscillations.

asStringPerc generates an sprintf statement based on the argument (#2168)

but sprintfs into a fixed sized buffer. So the value of that argument
can lead to a buffer overflow. Just check it against reasonable lower
and upper bounds.

Addresses https://github.com/supercollider/supercollider/issues/1158

Merge pull request #2106 from llloret/midi_windows_master

Make MIDI work on Windows

midi: windows: fix sysrt handling

Fix the interpretation of the MIDI sysrt messages

midi: implement MIDI system messages on Windows

Implementation of MIDI system messages for Windows. Initial testing with
loopback device.

midi: sysex output on windows

First stab at making the SysEx output work on Windows. Note that I have
not tested it with real HW yet, but I can see it getting to the PortMIDI
function to send the data, so it should be ok.

I am not sure if I have the proper external equipment to test it
properly, that's why I am publishing it now.

midi: windows fixed issue when disconnecting midi

Fixed problem when disconnecting MIDI device, since the ProcessMIDI
function could trigger in the middle of the disconnect, and it could
start believing that there was a MIDI in device, that was in the process
of being deallocated.

midi: windows - fix deadlock - issue #1046

This fixes issue #1046, by removing the deadlock condition. The idea is
to avoid acquiring the lang mutex while holding the the Midi mutex,
since the language may try to acquire the Midi mutex to do a MIDI out.

midi: more fixes for Windows implementation

- find correct number of ports when initializing.
- revert to not open input ports on init
- keep track of which input ports have been opened to avoid closing ones
that are not open

midi: make midi work in Windows

Some initial changes to make midi work in Windows. The main things are:
- Do not open the Microsoft MIDI Mapper device, otherwise we get
multiple allocation errors (I am guessing that the midi mapper tries to
open another device too).
- Open MIDI Input devices on init, if requested by numInputs
- Pass numIn and numOut to the init call, as received by the language
(but is gets 0, when nil, this is wrong)
- For the time being, do nothing on MIDI reset

I have not tested connecting and disconnecting discrete MIDI ports for
now.

Topic/server unresponsive (#1935)

* class library: server is marked as unresponsive instead of dead when asleep

* class library and ide: display unresponsive server app.

Some refactoring of the serverRunning_ method. This method is now really used to
set the state if known. If unknown, like from the aliveThread, we call
updateRunningState instead. This method will not change serverRunning if false,
but will mark the server as unresponsive. Only if we quit the server from sclang
explicitly, we call serverRunning_ directly.

* class library: server - fix update server running state

* class library: when killing all servers on the commandline, don't wait for them to close down. They won't reply anyway.

* class library: move out status updater functionality

* class library: server notify via status

* class library: move serverRunning methods to server. On the whole it is for efficiency to keep at least serverRunning in Server, because this method is called all the time

* class library: server clientID setter is protected

* class library: rename ServerStatus to ServerStatusWatcher

* class library: move most status to the server status watcher class

* class library: move more state to ServerStatusWatcher

* scide: if unresponsive, label yellow independent of running or not

* class library: fix update call, remove postings.

* class library: avoid erroneous thread creation on cmd-period

Because CmdPeriod calls resumeThreads, all registered servers, if booted or not, have aliveThreads. This patch fixes that impolite misbehavior.

* class library: remove unrelated debugging statements

* class library: server: fix typos and comment

jack: add metadata support

JACK patch bays by default order JACK client ports alphabetically. If
SuperCollider is run with 10+ input or output ports, patch bays get the
port order wrongly.

There is a metadata key to manually set the order of JACK ports. This
commit sets that key if the JACK metadata API has been detected by
CMake (old JACK versions do not ship the needed headers).

The commit being about metadata also sets the pretty name metadata which
is shown by JACK batch bays instead of the raw port name.

This commit adds jackey via 'git subtree' to external_libraries, a
public header with JACK metadata keys used by multiple developers of
JACK clients and patch bays.

sclang: Fix to get Object: render to work on Windows

Due to reliance on "rm" command render invocations such as the one below threw an error on Windows.

Pbind(\instrument, \default).render(thisProcess.platform.recordingsDir +/+ "test.aif", 1)

Error is "ERROR: Invalid option ;" from scsynth.exe.

Instead of "rm" I propose to rely on File.delete instead.

class library: add storeOn support to TwoWayIdentityDictionary

TwoWayIdentityDictionary has a rather minimalistic interface compared
to Dictionary. This patch adds the proper interface for supporting
archiving and asCompileString conversion. This fixes  #1699.

help files: warning in filter UGen help files about filter frequencies close to zero

related to https://github.com/supercollider/supercollider/commit/cc8c6fb9db42d25190cc1bff6ec9c31f66a55950

class library: NodeProxy mold fix fadeTime

When reshaping the node proxy, the monitor is also adjusted. It failed
to take into account the fadeTime argument passed to the mold message.
This patch fixes it by explicitly passing it on to the monitor.

class library: NodeProxy - overriding default reshaping works

So far, nil was used as meaning both “not specified” and “do not
reshape”. This ambiguity made it impossible to locally override a
global (defaultReshaping) setting. This commit makes it explicit, and
calls it “static”.

use "Walk Like and Egyptian" aka K&R braces for all class definitions

Sublime Text syntax grammar does not do multi-line matching,
so all editors that use this (including Atom and its symbol matching)
cannot detect classes defined as

    MyClass
    {

    }

This also makes all classes in the class lib consistent in style which is nice
for everybody.

var pathName = "/Users/crucial/Library/Application Support/SuperCollider/downloaded-quarks/splines";
(pathName.dirname+/+"*").pathMatch.detect{|x|x.withoutTrailingSlash.compare(pathName.withoutTrailingSlash)==0}.notNil

scel: Fix mode-line update

`(force-mode-line-update)`  updates only the mode-line of  the current buffers. Providing a non-nil argument updates the mode-line of all buffers. This is particularly useful when having a split view with the server buffer and another buffer where current buffer is not the server buffer. (probably  a very common use case).

class library: unordered concatenation

Because wslib is very popular and implements ++ (concatenation) for dictionary, there is a lot of code around that breaks when wslib is removed. While usually, concatenation assumes ordered collections, it does make sense for unordered ones and is less error prone than writing:

collection.copy.addAll(otherCollection)

and for dictionary:

collection.copy.putAll(otherCollection)

So the best solution is to add ++ also for unordered collections, which is what this commit does. Fixes #1653.

server: Assume requested SR was successfully set

Setting sample rate in CoreAudio is actually an asynchronous operation - you request a sample rate change, and some time in the future it (probably) happens and you are called back about it. This is a problem for us because (a) SC doesn't support the sample rate changes once the server is started, and (b) our startup routine is totally synchronous anyway. Prior to this change, when we requested a custom sample rate, we would do the SetProperty and then shortly after ask CoreAudio for the device sample rate. If the operation had not been completed yet, we would get the OLD rate - the device would it's SR to the requested shortly after, and we would effectively be running the server at the wrong rate. Now, we *assume* that a successful SetProperty has changed the sample rate, and just use the rate we set instead of requesting from CoreAudio. We can still be incorrect if the SR doesn't actually change, but at least we're correct MOST of the time. To increase the changes of success, we query CoreAudio for valid sample rates, and set our requested rate based on those.

A proper fix for this would be to have a properly asynchronous driver startup procedure, where we request all the properties we want, and then wait for callbacks indicating the changes have "taken" before continuing. Note that requesting a buffer size still has the same problem - the fix should be identical - this should be fixed in a different CL.

Merge pull request #1507 from porres/patch-1

Update LFPar.schelp

Update Resonz.schelp

I made this changes because the help file of Ringz did relate to this object, but the opposite didn't happen. I think it only makes sense to point the relationship in both help files.

By the way, I did also just proposed a change in Rigngz's help file, as the relationship to Resonz was misleading.

Update Ringz.schelp

I made this change because the help file, as it was originally written, did really throw me off by believe that both Resonz and Ringz were in fact the exact same filter, being the only exception how you set the filter parameters. I added more information regarding the relationship between Resonz and Ringz so the differences and similirarities between them is made clearer. 

The help file of Resonz should also be updated to also state the relatioship between these two objects. It doesn't make sense to make the relationship in this help file but completely omit it in the other one. So I'm also going to propose some changes in the help file of Resonz to make it like this one.

ide: Workaround for completion help view crash

Dragging or copying text from the help view that pops up during completion results in a crash. It appears that QT deletes the QMimeData corresponding to the copied/dragged chunk too soon, and referencing it later on causes a crash. I attempted various overrides of createMimeDataFromSelection (returning e.g. plain text, etc), and it always crashed except when we simply return NULL. This results in text from that view not being copyable / draggable but this is better than a crash. This is probably a deep QT bug.

sclang: fix crash during SerialPort cleanup

The SerialPort destructor calls join on it's thread, which crashes if run from the thread itself. To close, SerialPort is flagged such that the thread will exit it's run loop, close the port, and then call prDoneAction, which in turn calls prCleanup - this ALWAYS happens from the SerialPort thread itself, meaning it always crashes.

This fixes by (a) ensuring that prCleanup always defers to the main thread, (b) erroring the primitive if we try to call it from the SerialPort thread, (c) asserting if we hit the destructor on the SerialPort thread (which should make problems here easier to track, at least). We are currently not destroying SerialPort backend objects (or removing the threads) properly when the language quits - I'll fix this in a separate commit, though there are no bad effects at the moment (unless you count computer scientists giving annoyed looks).

sclang: workaround webkit scrollbar hiding bug

A bug in qt webkit results in animations related to scrollbar opacity and hidden-ness pointing to the QWebView instead of the scrollbars (see https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=104116). As a result, the QWebView gets hidden instead of the scrollbars in many cases. This bug was seemingly fixed, but in a very specific and limited way - either it has regressed, or we're running afoul because of our custom style. Regardless, we can work around by implementing the same fix referenced in the aforementioned bug in our own custom styles. Also  - this change removes an OLD webkit scrollbar hack, because it appears to no longer be a problem. This MAY fix the problems with help disappearing in the IDE as well.

classlib: Don't pass unprintables in key events

Documentation says that the char argument of keydown/keyup events is the printable character typed, or nil. We are currently passing an ascii zero character instead - the fix is to pass nil in this case.

help: add note about new HID implementation

This fixes #1303.

sclang: set max scroll according to req'd value

Setting some geometry-related properties at view creation time gets a bit weird, because layout is often not calculated immediately. In case of #823, the initial layout of the view gets calculated in a slightly deferred event fired in response to .front(), meaning that when visibleOrigin_ is called, the scrollbars still haven't been adjusted according to the layed-out window contents (specifically, at creation time the max scroll value is 0). Fixing this by getting layout to happen at the right time is hard - fortunately, it looks like scrollbar behavior is smart enough that, when we request a specific visibleOrigin, we can simply increase the scrollbar max value as needed - even when manually setting a max, the scrollbars seem to re-adjust properly as the contents of the scroll area are sized.

ide: better newline behavior within brackets

This adds two additional conditions for creating a double-newline when hitting return w/in brackets. We should NOT add a double-newline if we're in between two closing brackets - i.e. ]], ]), etc.
And, we should NOT add a double-newline if the closing bracket to the right of the cursor is the first thing on the line.

This avoids several spurious double-newlines that are common in SC code (see bug #814, for example). Note that this still allows a double-newline if you're adding function arguments to a function over multiple lines. Hitting return in this case:
    ([1, 2], [3, 4],<return>)
(i.e. with a comma before the return) will create a double-newline.

lang: NetAddr: correctly disconnect tcp socket

NetAddr#disconnect should close the underlying boost TCP socket in order for the port to be available again for use, and should handle the common error that happen when shuting down the TCP connection, if the connection was already terminated from the other side. After the SC_TcpClientPort is closed it is no longer usable therefore the socket variable of NetAddr should be set to null, making NetAddr#isConnected correctly report the status of the connection.

ide: fix crash on session switch

The prevents a crash when iteratively closing all documents. Each doc close triggers a chain of signals that can result in - what appears to be - an already-removed document being referenced by a tab. This change prevents the crash directly by disconnecting the currentChanged signal, which avoids the chain of signals. It also adds some seatbelts in case of bad / null documents, and uses deleteLater() to delete the document, rather than a raw delete. The Document*'s should probably be changed to smart pointers - the signal logic when managing documents is complex enough that it's hard to analytically show that there isn't some pending signal or reference to a document floating around after DocumentManager::close(*) is called.

qtcollider: set painting object in beginPainting, not announcePainting

qtcollider: defer setPropery if called inside drawFunc

This should avert a crash when setting the background color of a UserView from inside a drawFunc. In general, it seems extremely unsafe to synchronously set a property of a UserView while *inside* of it's drawFunc. Most properties will behave more or less identically if the set is deferred, and for some (i.e. changing view geometry) this avoids very undefined and dangerous-seeming behavior.

Signed-off-by: Scott Wilson <i@scottwilson.ca>

lang: Unify time and scheduling approach across platforms

- standardise Main:elapsedTime across all platforms: use chrono::high_resolution_clock on all platforms. Windows and Linux reported elapsedTime as time since epoch rather than time since lang start. This is bad because it is inconsistent, misleading, and because time since epoch is usually from 1/1/1970, considerable resolution was lost when converted to seconds as a float. This has been corrected to match the original Mac behaviour.
- correct for drift against timeofday on all platforms
- remove elapsedRealTime(): This is now the same as elapsedTime, and was only used for calculating compile and init times. (Why was that more precise than lang scheduling?)

Signed-off-by: Scott Wilson <i@scottwilson.ca>

lang: Fix TCP bugs

This fixes Issue #1099. The problem was to do with the way in which incoming TCP messages were constructed before passing to the lang:

- The remote port info was not being set at all, and was then being converted from network to host order in ConvertReplyAddress. This was not needed as boost::asio::ip always gives ports in host order. UDP only worked because port was converted to network order and then back in ConvertReplyAddress, so that was removed as well.

- The received on port was being set to the remote port, so that was also corrected.

lang: Fix bug that occurred when multiple responder funcs respond to the same key, and one of them modifies the list of responders for that key

- This commit also improves FunctionList:copy to create a new internal array.

MIDI: Fix a crash on mac when initializing midi after a library recompile.

On mac, sclang can crash when MIDI is initialized after a library recompile (on my machine and a few others I've used, this occurs 100% of the time). This crash occurs in prListMIDIEndpoints, due to a null devname or endname because of a previous call that errors out. Trivially, we can stop the crash by protecting against cases where MIDIObjectGetStringProperty doesn't return a proper result. These calls were ultimately failing because calling MIDIClientCreate a second time after called MIDIClientDispose results in that call failing. The documentation is unclear exactly how CoreMIDI expects these to be called, but it implies that the normal lifetime of a client is one per app launch ("It is not essential to call this function; the CoreMIDI framework will automatically dispose all MIDIClients when an application terminates.") - in any case, our use case is pretty simple, and a crash is a crash..... This fixes the core problem by only initializing MIDI once, and then keeping that MIDI client for the rest of sclang's lifetime. Effectively, gMIDIClient becomes a singleton.

IDE: Workaround to prevent UDP event feedback loop (qt5.3 bug)

After qt5.3, booting the server from the IDE would cause 150%+ cpu usage due to this QT bug:
https://bugreports.qt-project.org/browse/QTBUG-39080

After some fiddling last night, this workaround bypasses god-knows-what mechanisms in Qt socket notification to avoid the feedback. Given all the weirdness I saw in the Qt sockets implementation, it might be better to move this to boost long term, but this works for now. :)

move sclang to the MacOS directory with the app executable

QT plugin loading is determined in part by the qt.conf file, which points to a Plugin dir. sclang seems to get confused by being adjacent to that file, and misunderstanding where it should load plugins from. Simply moving sclang is the simplest way I found to ensure both the IDE and sclang load plugins and do runtime linking successfully. There MAY be a better solution to be had - enabling the QT_DEBUG_PLUGINS env flag helps show what's going on - but this is working, and /MacOS is a fine and possibly more appropriate place for sclang anyway, so there it stays.

Classlib: GUI: Reinstate proper functioning of ObjectGui system

Patched by James Harkins <jamshark70@dewdrop-world.net>

Object:gui *should* look up the implementing class by the method
'guiClass'. Commit 019586cb0ba20d7c9d851e2449dac7911bbb0952 improperly
removed this and hardcoded ObjectGui instead -- thus breaking every
class that implements 'guiClass' but not 'gui'.

The crucial GUIs are not Qt views. They are more like Controllers
in MVC. 'guiClass' here was never a redirect and it shouldn't have
been touched.

scsynth + class lib: Server returns a clientID when clients are registered with notify.

- When a client registers for notification the server sends it a clientID
- If returned clientID has not been received previously this triggers new allocators.
- When a client turns off notification the clientID is freed and can be reassigned
- If the user explicitly supplies a clientID that one is used (backwards compatible).

Signed-off-by: Scott Wilson <i@scottwilson.ca>

lang: Move bus and buffer allocators from Republic's SharedServer to Server. Expose maxLogins to ServerOptions

- Bus and Buffer allocators have always been broken for multi-client servers. This fixes this basic functionality
- maxLogins exists as a server option, but was not exposed in ServerOptions. Explicitly setting it now allows you to set how the bus and buffer ranges will be divided.

Signed-off-by: Scott Wilson <i@scottwilson.ca>

Env: provide new step2 shape, which steps to a value at the end of a shape

the semantics of Env.xyc for \step is very awkward when using, because \step directly
jumps to the end value of a segment. this means that Env.xzc([[0, 0, \step], [1, 1, \step]])
will have the value 1 between time 0 and 1.
using \step2 instead of \step, the value between 0 and 1 will be 0, and it will jump to 1
at time 1

on top of the old one.

example line and show how to free them.

scide: sc_editor: include parenthesis in regionAroundCursor()

scide: sc_editor: include parenthesis in regionAroundCursor()

When evaluating a region, the evaluated code excludes the parenthesis
which define the region. If they are included instead, we avoid a
parse error when evaluating array shortcut notations like `(1..3)`.

scide: prevent erroneous overriding of shortcuts on Mac OS

On Mac OS, for some global menu items, there is a ShortcutOverride event
with key() == 0, which seems like a Qt bug. Text widgets accept all
ShortcutOverride events with key() < Qt::Key_Escape, which includes 0.
This patch ignores such erroneous ShortcutOverride events on global
application level.

SynthDesc/Def: Slightly rearrange the way SynthDef:add add a desc to a SynthDescLib. Add a dependancy hook to SynthDescLib for when new descs are added

The way this happened is a bit convoluted, and made adding a hook non-straightforward. This patch maintains the existing methods so as not to break code. It adds a new method to SynthDescLib. Users will be directed to use that to add to a lib, and only use the old methods to add to a dictionary.

qtcollider: sf view: fix loading non-power-of-two floating point files

Reading floating point files of non-power-of-two channel count into short
type buffer seems to be broken in libsndfile. Instead, we read into
temporary float buffer, and scale into final short buffer.

sc ide: improve server boot/quit actions

* Offer separate boot and quit actions.

  a menu placeholder and proxy.
* Update the unified action with text and shortcuts from the separate
  actions according to server status and configuration.
qtcollider: QKnob - let 'background' affect knob color

qtcollider: QView - do not block beginDrag if currentDrag is already set

Drag-and-drop operations initiated from outside sclang do not clear drag
data (i.e. currentDrag), so we have to trade off this sanity check for now.

Ultimately, things should be fixed by clearing currentDrag after external
DnD has finished. The issue is that there is no Qt event that would notify
about cancellation of DnD by the user. Maybe connecting to QMimeData
destruction signal would do.

An alternative would be to set and clear currentDrag at beginning and end
of every DnD event-handling method.

sclang: terminal client - fix and simplify request handling

The previous implementation could miss sig_stop and sig_recompile requests,
if they were issued between handling the request and clearing the request
flag.

This change corrects the algorithm, while slightly increasing the chance
that the same request needs to be performed multiple times if issued in
close succession.

qtcollider: deprecate QDialog:-getPaths
class library: remove GUI interfaces deprecated in 3.5
qtcollider: remove obsolete type translation code

qtcollider: streamline SC <-> Qt type translation

* Introduce TypeCodec, MetaType, and MetaValue classes:

- TypeCodec: template-based decoding/encoding from/to PyrSlot
- MetaType: akin to QMetaType, working with an indexed collection
  of registered TypeCodecs
- MetaValue: akin to QVariant, but related to MetaType

* When invoking functions via Qt meta-object system, allocate arguments
  on stack using alloca() instead of on heap.

allows a unified way to specify directories searched by FindXxx cmake
modules as well as the bundling script.

Fix Event getMsgFunc so that it correctly looks up the SynthDesc

The commit 53e2a814c7c4b123703964e40721202199c8635e introduced a bug by
replacing .asSymbol with .asDefName, but the latter returns a String,
while the SynthDescLib is indexed by symbols. This commit fixes it by
converting it back to a symbol if it was not already a symbol.

mSaveTime isn't initialized, but is used to filter events from

of events, only some of which are file modificaitons. If mSaveTime
isn't initialized, these will randomly fire / not fire.

scide: ScCodeEditor - use tokens for selection on double-click

We could instead use the new ScLexer to tokenize text on-the-fly
(even comments, etc.), but that wouldn't allow bracket matching based
on TokenIterator.

To tokenize comments, strings, etc. we should either combine the two
approaches, or permanently tokenize that text during syntax highlighting.

scide: introduce ScLexer class

Separate lexical analysis out of SyntaxHighlighter into a separate class,
for code intelligibility as well as potential code re-use.

scide: method call aid - implement insertion and switching of argument name

When typing a method call, and the cursor is after a comma or a start of
an argument name, pressing 'Tab' will insert the next argument name. The
argument name starting immediately before cursor will be replaced.

Likewise, 'Backtab' (Shift+Tab) will insert the previous argument name.

scide: streamline sclang response dispatching

class it makes most sense.

scide: PostWindow - remove unnecessary '\n' character handling

Should fix issue #533, while avoiding regression to issue #436.

The special handling of '\n' was there in the first place because
the SCProcess::scPost(QString) signal was being abused for internal
IDE status notifications. Now that we have a proper status bar, we
can get rid of this complication.

The handling of '\n' was faulty anyway, because on Windows a new line
consists of 2 characters, not jut '\n', so if this is to be reinstated
for some reason, we need a different implementation anyway.

bracket type is different, but color differently in such case, so as to
indicate syntactical error.

Moreover, only match bracket pairs that do not contain cursor.

sc ide: DocumentManager: always resolve paths to canonical form

sc ide: fix recent documents menu

Do not reload the list of recent documents from configuration file on
every request from settings manager to apply settings, as that would
discard changes occurred at runtime.

Instead, only load the list once at start up.

sc ide: unify find-replace panel and command-line into one toolbox

This avoids unnecessary GUI bloat by only allowing one of find,
replace, and command-line panels to be visible at a time.

Also, actions are added to the View menu that control the
visibility of the tool panels.

qtcollider: StackLayout: calculate size policies based on stacking mode

When stacking mode is StackOne (only one widget visible at a time), only
include that widget in calculation of sizeHint() and minimumSizeHint().

Moreover, implement expandingDirections() following the same principle.

qtcollider: separate QtCollider::StackLayout to support reuse

Make our custom reimplementation of QStackedLayout independent from
QtCollider code so it can be reused outside of QtCollider (e.g. in the
Qt IDE).

Effectively, the QcStackLayout is split into two classes:
* QtCollider::StackLayout = generic implementation.
* QcStackLayout = subclass of the above with the addition of QtCollider
  specifics

or the current region if any, or the current line.

sclang: run all finalizers on library shutdown

Previously, only the already unreachable finalizers were run.
However, shutting down the library implicitly makes all objects unreachable,
so all finalizers need to be run.

qtcollider: remove unnecessary duplicate code

QWindow:-onClose is a duplication of QView:-onClose. Remove it, and instead
just forward to the view's method.

complicates usage. It is more practical to represent YAML
sequences as QStringLists.

qtcollider: optimization - do not use QLayout to handle the 'resize' flag

Simplify the implementation of traditional layouts to avoid putting a
QLayout on every single view.

qtcollider: optimize QcWidgetFactory::newInstance()

Most optimization comes from replacing a call to QMetaObject::invokeMethod()
with getting the QMetaMethod and calling its invoke() directly.
qtcollider: optimization - use Symbols to reference C++ methods and properties

qtcollider: optimization - use QVector instead of QHash as event handler container

We typically have rather small amount of event handlers, say in the range
of 7 - 12. Using QHash in this case is more expensive than QVector, both
for insertion/addition and for lookup.

QVector is also faster than std::vector at lookup, although slower at addition.
qtcollider: optimization - avoid connecting signals with unnormalized signatures
qtcollider: optimization - avoid a signal connection at QObject construction

qtcollider: optimization - partially revert event handling changes

Setting an event handler adds to a QHash, which is a considerable
cost. So instead of setting all main event handlers at every view
instantiation, revert to only setting the handlers when necessary.

qtcollider: improve key propagation in QListView and QTreeView

Override Qt's default behavior so as to always accept arrow keys,
Page Up, Page Down, Home, and End keys, thus preventing them from
propagating to parent when the scroller meets top or bottom.

qtcollider: add QWebView:-onJavaScriptMsg

It allows to set a handler for JavaScript console messages
(e.g. errors). The handler is passed the following arguments
at evaluation:
- view
- message
- line number
- source ID
SCDoc: fix escaping of & < and >

qtcollider: implement drag-and-drop for data outside SC

The DnD data from outside SC is stored into
QView:*currentDrag as follows:

- URL (e.g. file from a file manager) becomes a String.
  Multiple URLs become an Array of Strings.
  The "file://" scheme is always dropped.

- Text simply becomes a String.

Other types of data are not supported (yet).
qtcollider: QObject:-getProperty: turn an error into a debug warning
help: fix incorrect info in EnvelopeView documentation
help: update EnvelopeView documentation

qtcollider: QEnvelopeView: improve node selection API and UI

*** API ***

* -index: returns the lower selected index.

* -lastIndex: returns the index last selected regardless of
current selection.

*** UI ***

* Arrows: move nodes when no modifiers keys pressed.

* Alt + Arrows: exclusively select the node after/before the
last/first selected node, wrapping.

* Shift + Arrows: extend selection to the left/right,
non-wrapping.

qtcollider: QTextField: never propagate Enter to parent

Enter triggers the action, so it shouldn't be propagated.

qtcollider: QTextView: improve -enterInterpretsSelection

Make the -enterInterpretsSelection flag allow interpretation of
current line, when there is no selection.

per server. This fixes 2 issues in implementation:

sc ide: optimize and simplify syntax highlighting algorithm

* Improve and optimize syntax matching regexps

* Change algorithm: only match regexps starting at current position
  in text; if there's a match move position behind the match; if
  there is no match, move position forward by 1 character;
  then repeat.

* The order in which regexps are tested becomes important, so fix
  that order where necessary.

but it will warn if the methods argument-signatures does not match.

qtcollider: QEnvelopeView: implement 2 drawing styles

* The 'dots' style (visually same as previous appearance) only
  supports equal thumb width and height. If different height and
  width are set for an element, the smaller of those is applied to
  size in both directions

* The 'rects' style is the traditional appearance with rectangular
  elements, and labels drawn inside the elements.

* For backwards compatibility, as soon as -thumbWidth, -thumbHeight,
  -setThumbWidth or -setThumbHeight methods are used, the style is
  switched to 'rects'. One can still switch the style to 'dots'
  afterwards.
qtcollider: QEnvelopeView: allow setting different size to each element

qtcollider: QSlider: improvements regarding 'step' and rounding

* Implement pixelStep method
* Set default step to 0.
* Whenever in/decrementing, use max(step, pixelStep)
* When value changes, round it to step modified by modifier keys
  (other kits always round to unmodified step)
* Do not round when step itself changes
  (unlike other kits)

* Also, replace all floats with doubles
qtcollider: get rid of many floats in favour of doubles

qtcollider: fix passing char to key actions on Alt + [A-Z]

In Cocoa, as well as in Qt on Linux, Alt modifier does not affect
the char passed.

This is not the case with Qt on Mac OS X, where ASCII 0 is produced,
so we override the default behavior.

qtcollider: fix passing char to key actions on Ctrl + [A-Z]

When Ctrl modifier is pressed, Cocoa, as well as Qt on Linux,
map A to Z keys to ASCII codes 1 - 26.

This is not the case with Qt on Mac OS X, so implement this
mapping on our own.

qtcollider: simplify passing char to keyboard actions

Extra: implement Char <-> QChar translation.

class library: Plotter: fix drawing on user-provided parent

This fixes Plotter drawing when a parent is provided by
the user, and the Plotter bounds are not at 0@0.

Changes:

* Always draw on the internal UserView instead of the parent,
  regardless of whether the parent Window was constructed by
  the Plotter. This makes calculation of bounds easier.

* Calculate drawing bounds relative to the internal UserView
  instead of the parent.

* Do not inset the drawing if a parent is provided by the user.

sclang(win): remove a busy-waiting loop under mimicry

The implementation of the input-reading thread on Windows was
mistakingly thought to be sleeping while there is no input. In fact,
it was busy-waiting.

The reason is that the Win API function WaitForMultipleObjects does
not work on anyonymous pipes. Instead of waiting, it always returns
immediately as if the pipe was signalled.

Due to limitations of anonymous pipes on Windows, we have no choice
but to use a blocking read. This also means we have no mechanism for
interrupting the reading thread while blocked. Effectively, when
quitting sclang we have no choice but to let the thread live on and
be terminated automatically when the process terminates.

cmake: support user-defined libsndfile dependencies

Setting the SNDFILE_FIND_QUIETLY variable did not do the right job.
It would only silence the warning, but the find_library() call would
still fail if the module was used more than once:

The first time it would not fail as the library variable was set by
the user, but would apparently clear the user status from the variable,
so the second time the check would regard it as a non-user variable,
and fail.

sclang: bind Ctrl-T to CmdPeriod

Previously, Ctrl-B was bound, but on Windows, the same ASCII code
appears to be produced by the left arrow key, which cripples the
command line navigation.

Instead, bind Ctrl-T. There's several reasons to support that:
1. it makes sense lexically (as in "Terminate");
2. it does not appear to be bound to a signal by any standard;
3. it is not expected to be bound to another important terminal
feature, as for example backward navigation - it is described as
intended for "stopping an auxiliary device".
4. 'T' is usually far enough on keyboards from 'X', that we use
for library recompilation

sclang: increase udp receive buffer size

the osc parser of sclang assumes that the full message is placed in the
buffer. if this is not the case, it crashes. this happens e.g. when
replying to g_queryTree when may synths are running.

this patch is merely a workaround, as it just increases the buffer size
and moves the buffer to the SC_UdpInPort and SC_UdpCustomInPort classes

OSX: install libs into bundle explicitly

commit changes that let cmake's Xcode project build

OSX: Bundle everything inside the .app, except examples/, README, ChangeLog.txt, etc.

This is the standard way to bundle an .app on OSX, and it fixes the library
references in sclang and scsynth binaries, which now links to the libraries
and frameworks bundled with the .app. Note that since sclang links to the
bundled Qt frameworks, it can not be installed system-wide. But you can install
simple wrapper-scripts into a folder in your PATH.

We also remove the hack in SC_StandAloneInfo_Darwin.cpp to detect standalones
and instead simply pass a SC_STANDALONE definition from cmake.

A MOVED_STUFF.txt file was added in case people wonder where everything has gone,
and README.txt and README_OS_X.txt was updated.

Move configured SCVersion.sc -> SCVersion/SCVersion.sc

This way, <build_dir>/SCVersion/ can be included by langConfig to get
the correct version for people using langConfig to run the class library
from the source tree instead of the installed one.

scsynth: don't preload plugins on 64bit platforms

for some reason, preloading corrupts the stack of scsynth, causing the
following error:

$ ./scsynth -u 7777
...
program received signal EXC_BAD_ACCESS, Could not access memory.
Reason: KERN_INVALID_ADDRESS at address: 0x00007fff00000030
0x000000010002bd65 in World_New (inOptions=0x7fff00000000) at SC_World.cpp:343
343                     world->hw->mAllocPool = new AllocPool(malloc, free,
inOptions->mRealTimeMemorySize * 1024, 0);
(gdb) bt
#0  0x000000010002bd65 in World_New (inOptions=0x7fff00000000) at
SC_World.cpp:343
#1  0x0000000100003162 in main (argc=3, argv=0x7fff5fbff8e0) at
scsynth_main.cpp:321

disabling the code on x86_64 works around the issue. ia32 does not seem
to be affected

sclang: Scheduler and AppClock fixes

AppClock:

* Let AppClock call its *prSchedNotify method instead of
  Scheduler, so the latter works with other clocks.

Scheduler:

  mode in AppClock.

Signed-off-by: Tim Blechmann <tim@klingt.org>

class library: SynthDef - lazy implementation of removeUGen

the original removeUGen implementation had linear complexity, as both
Array.remove and SynthDef-indexUGens a O(n). to avoid performance penalties
of successive calls, we now use a lazy implementation: instead of removing
the ugen directly, we replace it with nil.
when the graph optimization is finished, we remove all nil entries and re-index
the ugens.

this heavily speeds up the generation of large synthdefs.

class library: SynthDef - replaceUGen should keep descendants

qtcollider: QPenPrinter: do not crash if destroyed while dialog open

Also, keep the dialog alive for the lifetime of QPenPrinter, so
it can preserve state when shown multiple times.
class library: QPenPrinter: add convenience *print method

qtcollider: pass SC arguments directly to C++ constructor

Implement passing up to 10 arguments of QObject's SC constructor
to the constructor of the implementing C++ class.

Any non-default C++ constructor must be declared with Q_INVOKABLE.
In order for such constructor to be invoked, all SC arguments must
be of type that will translate exactly to C++ constructor's types.

If arguments are given to the SC constructor, but they don't match
any invokable C++ constructor, the construction will fail and a SC
error will be thrown.

Every C++ class still needs to have a default constructor.
Constructing with no arguments thus never fails.

Merge branch 'topic/shmem_server'

Add QPen printing support (and PDF export) with new QPenPrinter class.

QPenPrinter-showDialog(okFunc,cancelFunc) shows a print dialog to configure the printer
and calls okFunc when user presses "print".

QPenPrinter-print(drawFunc) calls drawFunc where QPen operates on the configured printer.
All the normal Pen methods can be used inside drawFunc.
qtcollider: a little clean-up

qtcollider: construct all SC types at Qt -> SC type conversion

Construct all Point, Rect, Color and QPalette involved in Qt to
SC type conversion immediately at conversion, thus avoiding the
need to construct them beforhand in SC.

Notable effects:

* Any type can be returned by QObject-getProperty without the need
  to pass an instance of the type to the method.

* Any type can be passed to SC in an Array

* Any type can be passed to SC as signal argument

* Any type can be returned by QObject-invokeMethod
sclang: improve some status messages

sclang: fix quitting when local server is booted.

Instead of signaling shutdown to the input thread by closing the
control pipe, rather write a character to it.

Child processes, like scsynth, inherit the pipe in an open state,
so sclang closing the pipe will not wake up select() on the pipe.

class library: QStethoscope2: use default server if none given

class library: make QStethoscope2 more robust

* Better synchronization with server, so as to minimize synth
  creation and ensure all created synths are freed.

* Use unique synth def name for every stethoscope instance, due
  to potential race between synth def loading and synth creation.

* Start and stop along with the server, and reallocate ScopeBuffer
  on server reboot.

* Implement -setProperties.

class library: ScopeBuffer: update interface

* A ScopeBuffer always occupies a single index, regardless of
  the number of channels it operates on.

* Rate of scoped buses is irrelevant for ScopeBuffer.

* We keep numChannels variable as useful information.

packages.sc: remove hackaround now that Class-filenameSymbol behaves the same on osx and linux

Don't resolve symlinks in String-standardizePath. Add new String-realPath that does.

This makes String-standardizePath, Class-filenameSymbol and String-realPath behave
the same on all platforms regarding symlinks.

String-standardizePath did never resolve symlinks on OSX, only in linux.
Resolving symlinks means using realpath() which would always return an absolute path,
but a couple of uses in main class lib expects it not to do that.
The new String-realPath works the same on all platforms that supports symlinks, and
returns nil for non-existent paths.

  even if resulting state is no current item.

plugins: implement LinLin as pseudo-ugen

LinLin is essentially a MulAdd with a specific coupling between the
parameters. Implementing it as pseudo-ugen has the advantage that the
implementation can make use of the highly optimized MulAdd ugens, parameter
ramping to avoid zipper noise and synthdef-based muladd optimizations.

qt gui: implement QObject: -properties and -methods

The new methods retrieve property names and method signatures from
Qt meta-object system.

QObject: -methods allows selection according to method type via
arguments: plain methods, signals or slots. By default it returns
invokable methods, i.e. plain methods and slots.

  contents.

  instead of all contents.

qtcollider: refactor drag-and-drop for robustness

* only ever use SC handlers if drag originated in SC.

* use all SC handlers or none, avoid mixing them with those of
  the widget implementation

* instead of passing data of external drags to SC, let the widget
  implementation handle it

* try to store data of drags originating in SC in the Qt drag data
  object, thus making it available to the widget implementation,
  as well as other applications

scel: keep command fifo alive for the lifetime of sclang

When sclang recompiled the class library, it would close its writing
end of the fifo, which in turn would trigger fifo deletion in scel.

This starts a dummy cat process with output redirected to the fifo,
so as to keep the fifo open as long as we desire.
